ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Arabic improved significantly, able to master discussions about politics, democracy, human rights and climate change, as well as some literary criticism.
This course greatly improved my speaking and listening ability in Arabic. It also improved my reading and writing skills and gave me an introduction to the difficulties and joys of translation.

I learned about Arabic literature and various topics of interest in the Middle East/Arab media. I developed my Arabic skills, particularly writing and speaking. I also had the chance to learn a little about literary translation and work on translation projects.
Developed stronger skills in Arabic conversation, translation/reading, presentation, policy discussion of the Arab world
Well I think my Arabic grew somewhat though I think it could have grown more with a different Professor and a different course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very strong as it is. Perhaps the literature section could move to the end, as it was by far the most challenge aspect of the course

The main strength of this course was its emphasis on Arabic conversation. The chance to meet three times a week and engage with my classmates completely in Arabic made my language skills improve in a way unprecedented during the rest of my time studying Arabic at Yale. Professor Elbousty worked to curate a class environment where mistakes were understood and encouraged, which made me feel comfortable participating in conversation. Other strengths of the course included the reading material (I really enjoyed the short stories we read at the beginning of the semester, and the news articles we read for the rest of the semester sparked interesting conversations in class) and, of course, Professor Elbousty himself. He is a generous teacher.
This course could be improved with a bit more clear communication of the course schedule from the outset. We sometimes were a bit confused with what we had to do and when we had to do it (though Professor Elbousty was responsive to our questions and ended up making a very helpful assignment schedule for everyone). I also think it could be helpful to have the same TA grade our reading responses as teaches us on Fridays. Some of my classmates and I had questions about our reading response grades but, since we never saw the TA that graded them, were unable to have them answered. (The TA that taught us on Fridays was absolutely wonderful, though.)

Professor Elbousty is a great strength of the course. I liked his division of literary and media Arabic with many interesting units. I think it would help to ease students into the class by starting with media Arabic, since literature was a little overwhelming at first. I valued the small class size and the ability to practice Arabic by just discussing the readings. Lastly, I had a lot of fun with the literary translation aspect of the course -- the speakers we had were really cool!

I would have appreciated more opportunities for grammar study -- I think there are some concepts I've missed or forgotten, or just things that I haven't learned yet, that would be nice to refresh. If there was time outside of class to ask grammar questions, or a writing workshop for our weekly reflections or something like that, it would have helped me improve my Arabic even more. The other thing that could be improved is more clear guidelines and schedules for assignments, since sometimes that was unclear or last-minute.

Strengths:
-very relevant topics covered (migration, Islam and democracy, etc.)
-good balance of work-- enough outside of class to continue improving but not overwhelming
-well-facilitated class discussion

Improve:
-might be helpful to have vocabulary tests to ensure students are retaining new words
-many schedule changes throughout the semester

Professor Elbousty needs to grade and look at the writing the students hand in. This is ridiculous. In a language class in any other school or program it would be unheard for a professor to not give constant feedback to the students writing: this is part of language learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, take this course! You will improve in the Arabic skills that matterreading, listening, speaking, and writingand will not find your time wasted with those that are less relevant outside of the academyMSA/Classical-specific grammar, etc. And you will do this all in a supportive and energetic environment.
Yes! Arabic is a wonderful language, Professor Elbousty is a fantastic professor, and you'll improve your Arabic so much by reading, writing, and discussing these texts.

I wouldnt recommend some course (with some caveats). If youve already taken some higher level Arabic then sure the ambitions in this course might suit you. But this course does not serve as a reasonable leap after L4 Arabic.
